DOCNAME: CASE OF ZAYTSEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial;Violation of Article 13 - Right to an effective remedy
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They are relatives .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant lodged an action before the ORG of GPE against a private company and its owner , PERSON , claiming execution of a contract and compensation for damage . According to the ORG , the action was lodged on DATE .

CARDINAL . The Nevskiy District Court fixed a hearing for DATE and ordered the first applicant to provide a detailed calculation of the damages claimed . The first applicant submitted the calculation and amended his claims .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG adjourned the examination of the action because the first applicant had not followed the pre - trial procedure for settling the dispute .

CARDINAL . DATE the first applicant appealed against the decision of DATE to GPE . On DATE he lodged another action before the ORG against PERSON seeking compensation for damage and execution of a contract . The action was based on the same set of facts as the action of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE GPE upheld the decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG partly granted the action of DATE . The judgment was quashed on appeal on DATE and a re - examination of the case was ordered .

CARDINAL . Having received the case file , on DATE the ORG joined the CARDINAL sets of the proceedings pertaining to the applicant ’s actions and listed a hearing for DATE . DATE ORG fixed CARDINAL hearings , of which , according to the ORG , CARDINAL hearings in DATE , CARDINAL hearing in DATE and CARDINAL hearings in DATE were adjourned due to the parties’ failure to attend . The first applicant , relying on a letter of DATE from a deputy president of ORG , disputed the ORG ’s assertion , arguing that CARDINAL hearing in DATE had been postponed due to the parties’ absence , CARDINAL had been adjourned because the presiding judge had been involved in other unrelated proceedings or had been ill and the remaining CARDINAL hearings had been adjourned because the respondent had defaulted .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on CARDINAL DATE the first applicant , who at that time lived in the town of PERSON , asked ORG to examine the action in his absence and to serve him with a copy of the judgment . The first applicant provided the ORG with copies of summonses for the hearings , neither of which contained a notification that his presence before ORG was mandatory .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG partly accepted the action . The first applicant appealed . On DATE ORG adjourned the appeal proceedings and asked the first applicant to pay a court fee .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following a complaint by the first applicant , GPE quashed the decision of DATE and accepted the appeal . On DATE ORG quashed the judgment of DATE in part and sent the case for a fresh examination .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant once again asked ORG to consider the case in his absence .
CARDINAL . As it appears from the parties’ submissions , after ORG had received the case file from GPE , it fixed the first hearing for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG postponed the hearing . According to the Government , ORG held that the first applicant ’s presence was mandatory . They further submitted that summonses had been served on the parties , including the first applicant , with a note stating that their presence was required .

CARDINAL . Hearings scheduled for DATE and DATE were also adjourned due to the first applicant ’s absence . According to the Government , summonses containing an order for the first applicant ’s presence had been served on him in due time . Copies of the summonses presented by the first applicant , including those for the hearings scheduled for DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE , did not contain notification that his presence was mandatory .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG discontinued the examination of the action because the first applicant had defaulted at the hearings on DATE , DATE and DATE and had apparently lost interest in his case .

CARDINAL . The first applicant was not notified of the decision of DATE . Accordingly , he complained to various domestic officials and ORG of GPE about the excessive length of the proceedings in his case .

CARDINAL . On DATE GPE , in reply to numerous complaints by the first applicant , sent a letter informing him that on DATE the proceedings in his case had been discontinued due to his failure to attend hearings . ORG , explained in detail to the first applicant the various judicial avenues he could follow if he wanted to challenge the decision of DATE . A copy of the decision of DATE was not enclosed .

CARDINAL . The first applicant asked the President of ORG to serve him with the decision of DATE . He also argued that he had requested ORG to examine his action in his absence and that therefore his absence from the hearings should not have been interpreted as proof that he had lost interest in the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG President informed the first applicant that his requests for the examination of his action in his absence had been included in the case file and that ORG had taken them into consideration . However , ORG had considered that the first applicant ’s presence at the hearings had been absolutely necessary and thus , following unsuccessful attempts to obtain his attendance , on DATE it had decided to discontinue the examination of the case . The President of ORG enclosed a copy of the decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE GPE office , in response to complaints by the applicant about the discontinuation of the proceedings , once again informed the first applicant of the procedure for challenging the decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . The RSFSR Code on Civil Procedure of DATE ( in force at the material time ) provided that civil cases were to be prepared for a hearing DATE after the action had been lodged with the court . Civil cases were to be examined DATE after the preparation for the hearing had been completed ( LAW )

CARDINAL . Summonses were to be served on the parties and their representatives in a way that allowed them enough time to attend the hearing on time and prepare their case . If necessary , the parties could be summoned by a phone call or a telegram ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . NORP Parties could ask a court to examine a case in their absence and to serve them with a copy of a judgment . A court could decide that the presence of a party was mandatory on the basis of the particular circumstances of a case ( LAW .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL set out a list of grounds for issuing an interim decision on discontinuation of the proceedings ( определение об оставлении заявления без рассмотрения ) , that is , if parties failed to make use of a preliminary non - judicial avenue of solving a dispute ; if an action was lodged by an incapacitated person or by a person lacking the authority to act ; if the parties , who had not asked for the examination of a case in their absence , without valid reasons , failed to attend CARDINAL hearings and the court considered it impossible to decide the case on the basis of case file materials ; if a claimant , who had not asked for the examination of a case in his / her absence , failed to attend CARDINAL hearings and a respondent did not insist on the examination of the merits of the case ; and if the same dispute between the same parties was pending before a court .
CARDINAL . A copy of a decision on discontinuation of the proceedings was to be sent to the absent party DATE after its delivery ( LAW ) .
